item.title: Genshin Impact Version 5.6 Takes You Back to Mondstadt in May
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/genshin-impact-version-56

HoYoverse has revealed the release date for Genshin Impact Version 5.6, and the main story chapter in this update will take you back to the land of Mondstadt for an "interlude chapter".

After the last update took you to a lava-filled volcano and introduced you to the last tribe of Natlan, Version 5.6, also known as "Paralogism", takes things in a more nostalgic direction. It's launching across all platforms on May 7th.

In the new Archon Quest Interlude chapter, you'll travel back to Mondstadt in order to take part in an "unexpected trial" involving Albedo. You'll be investigating the crime associated with the trial, meeting figures from your past like Venti and the Knights of Favonius.

Not only that, but you'll be defending Mondstadt from monsters (or perhaps that should be mondsters), as well as taking part in a "magical trial" to secure the support of powerful mage Lady Alice in the defense of the city.

Two new characters will also be joining Genshin Impact in Version 5.6. The first, Escoffier, is a spear-wielding Cryo user who "blends culinary flair with elemental power". She can deal pretty heavy damage and heal allies thanks to her Cooking Mek.

Joining Escoffier in this update is Ifa, a 4-star Anemo catalyst wielder who hails from Natlan. He can automatically heal active characters when their HP drops below a certain point, making him ideal for players who prefer to get stuck into the action.

Escoffier and Ifa will be available during Version 5.6's first half, along with Navia. Following that, reruns of Kinich and Raiden Shogun will be available in the second half, and the Chronicled Wish is also coming back, this time with characters from Inazuma up for grabs.

As always, three codes are also available for you to grab some free stuff in Genshin Impact, and here they are.

  • GI56Paralogism - 100 Primogems, 10 Mystic Enhancement Ore
  • ChefEscoffier0507 - 100 Primogems, 5 Hero's Wit
  • IfaCacucu0507 - 100 Primogems, 50,000 Mora

Genshin Impact is available to play for free right now on PC, PlayStation, Xbox Series X|S, and mobile devices. Version 5.6, "Paralogism", launches on May 7th.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Cult Hit JRPG Breath of Fire IV Returns Via GOG
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/breath-of-fire-iv-gog

GOG has announced a re-release of the classic PS1-era JRPG Breath of Fire IV, which is now available via PC a quarter-century after its initial release on the PlayStation.

As revealed in a post on X, over 22,000 people voted for Breath of Fire IV's inclusion as part of GOG's Preservation Program, which aims to support games long after their publishers or developers cease doing so.

According to GOG, the new PC release of Breath of Fire IV, which appears to be based on the original 2003 PC version rather than the PS1 version, is "fully optimized" for modern machines, sporting Windows 10 and 11 support, English and Japanese localizations, and various new options.

Other than those improvements, though, this remains very much the same Breath of Fire IV you may already know and love from 2000, and if you don't (and you're a JRPG fan), then I'd recommend checking it out tout de suite.

It's not just Breath of Fire IV, either. Other games joining the GOG Preservation Program today include the likes of Worms Armageddon, Realms of the Haunting, and three Ultima games, thus "completing the Ultima series in the Program", according to GOG.

If you're not familiar with Breath of Fire IV, it is, as the name suggests, the fourth game in Capcom's Breath of Fire series. Like previous games, this one also has you playing as Ryu, although it's not the same Ryu in each game.

This time around, your perspective is split between Ryu, who's found naked in a sand ditch by allies Nina and Cray, and Fou-Lu, a recently-reawoken emperor looking to regain the throne he lost hundreds of years ago.

Gameplay-wise, the game is a fairly straightforward turn-based JRPG, although it's got some tricks up its sleeve that make it stand out in what was a pretty crowded market at the time.

Breath of Fire IV is available right now on PC via GOG. Here's hoping for a Breath of Fire III release sometime soon, as unlikely as that might be.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Resident Evil 4 Sales Top 10m, Village at 11m
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/resident-evil-4-sales-10m-village-11m

Capcom has announced a new sales milestone for flagship survival horror games Resident Evil 4 and Resident Evil Village, as well as new figures for several other games in the series.

In a post on X, Capcom reveals that Resident Evil 4 has hit ten million sales, which means the game has managed to pick up another million sales for itself between January and now.

Resident Evil Village, meanwhile, has crossed the eleven million mark. It crossed the ten million line in June last year, so it's taking a little longer to pass those milestones than Resident Evil 4, but that's still a pretty impressive performance nonetheless. Capcom also shared this cool artwork to commemorate the occasion.

In addition to these two figures, Capcom also announced new milestones for Resident Evil 2 and 3, although it's harder to tell whether these are sales figures or player counts, given that both games are available via Xbox Game Pass right now.

Resident Evil 7 has also passed the 15 million mark according to Capcom, but again, since that game has historically been available as part of Game Pass or PlayStation Plus, it's hard to say whether the figure refers to sales or simply player count.

In any case, the figures show that Capcom's Resident Evil franchise is still going strong, so hopefully, it won't be too long until the next installment of the franchise is revealed.

Roughly five years passed between the release of Resident Evil 6 and the semi-reboot Resident Evil 7: Biohazard, and a further four years went by until Village arrived, so by that logic, we should be getting fairly close to a Resident Evil 9 reveal, at the very least.

Until then, however, the various Resident Evil games are available across pretty much all platforms, so you can pick your poison when it comes to survival horror.
